results.byline: By Michael C. Bender and J. David Goodman
results.title: As Trump Rallies in Waco, His Followers Shore Up His 2024 Bid
results.abstract: Despite a pattern of dangerous, erratic behavior, the former president remains a strong front-runner for his party’s nomination. His durability stems from his most loyal supporters.

media.caption: Early polls show that former President Donald J. Trump has a commanding advantage in the 2024 Republican primary field, though surveys also suggest that many G.O.P. voters would prefer another nominee.
media.copyright: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times

results.title: These Devices Sickened Hundreds. The New Models Have Risks, Too.
results.abstract: Duodenoscopes — tubular cameras threaded into the intestine — with disposable parts were supposed to be safer. But the parts can fall off in the body, the F.D.A. warned.

media.caption: Duodenoscopes, which enter the upper part of the small intestine through the mouth to diagnose and treat diseases of the pancreas and the bile duct, are used in about 500,000 procedures a year in the U.S.

results.adx_keywords: Walking;Santiago de Compostela (Spain)
results.title: Whatever the Problem, It’s Probably Solved by Walking
results.abstract: A walk begins to carve out space between my thoughts that allows clarity to rise up through my shoes.

results.byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany, John Yoon and Karoun Demirjian
results.title: A Crypto Fugitive’s Very Public Life While on the Run
results.abstract: Do Kwon, the founder of the failed crypto company Terraform Labs, is facing charges by the authorities in both South Korea and the United States.

media.caption: On Thursday, Do Kwon, the founder of Terraform Labs, was arrested in Podgorica, the capital of Montenegro, as he and a travel companion tried to board a private flight.

results.title: George Washington University Is Moving on From ‘Colonials’
results.abstract: The move comes amid a reckoning of the fraught history of team names across American sports. Potential new names include: “Ambassadors,” “Blue Fog,” “Revolutionaries” and “Sentinels.”

media.caption: Abby Schaub, a George Washington University catcher, at an N.C.A.A. softball game this month.

results.title: Philadelphia Monitoring Water Supply After Chemical Spill
results.abstract: More than 8,000 gallons of an acrylic polymer solution leaked on Friday into a tributary of the Delaware River, a source of the city’s drinking water.

media.caption: Workers placed booms to contain a chemical spill in Otter Creek, a tributary of the Delaware River.

results.adx_keywords: Elderly;Content Type: Service;Anesthesia and Anesthetics;Tests (Medical);Surgery and Surgeons;Doctors;Volunteers and Community Service;Transportation
results.title: You May Need That Procedure. But Do You Really Need an Escort?
results.abstract: Following even basic screenings and operations, patients often must arrange for someone to deliver them home. For older people, it can be a tall order.

media.caption: Robert Lewinger, a retired lawyer who lives alone, can’t schedule any of the surgical procedures he needs unless he supplies the name and phone number of the person taking him home afterward. “It shouldn’t be so hard,” he said.
media.copyright: Janice Chung for The New York Times

results.title: When I Got Cancer, My Dreams Told Me What My Doctors Could Not
results.abstract: When all the rational decision-making options are bad, relying on dreams offers a different kind of logic that can be a lifesaver in its own way.

results.abstract: Kathryn Marie Gallagher, 35, whose body was found in her apartment in July, died from a lethal mix of fentanyl and alcohol, the New York City medical examiner said.

results.byline: By Justin Scheck and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
results.title: Stolen Valor: The U.S. Volunteers in Ukraine Who Lie, Waste and Bicker
results.abstract: People who would not be allowed anywhere near the battlefield in a U.S.-led war are active on the Ukrainian front, with ready access to American weapons.

media.caption: Axel Vilhelmsen trained Ukrainian soldiers last year as part of the Mozart Group, which two former Marines established to help Ukraine. It disbanded after one founder sued the other, alleging theft and harassment.
media.copyright: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times

results.title: American Expatriates in Paris Wish Emily Cooper Would Go Home
results.abstract: Real-life Emilys in Paris complain that the show’s heroine, clad in over-the-top couture and barely able to speak French, is giving them a bad name.

media.caption: Since its premiere, the hit Netflix series “Emily in Paris,” starring Lily Collins, has spawned a backlash among the French. Even more triggered, perhaps, are the real-life Emilys in Paris
